text:
GEORGE RIEDEL: Hi, I'm
George Riedel, a professor

here at Harvard Business School. I'm joined by four
of our students here. We welcome you to our
Facebook live session

to reach out to
veterans, to give you a better sense of what it's
like to be at Harvard Business School. I'll give you a brief
description of my background,

and I'm going to ask my
colleagues on the panel here to give you
their background. And then we'll
jump into some Q&A, and then save some time
for your questions.

Short version, I teach in
the first year program. I teach two subjects, TOM,
or Technology and Operations

Management, and LCA,
which is a leadership course in the second semester. Dad was in the military, my
brother's in the military,

so I've been close to the
military for quite some time. Prior to coming back
to teach at HBS, I spent a number of years
as a consultant at McKinsey,

and as a tech entrepreneur in a
range of different industries, as a CEO on various boards. So let me ask our
other panelists here,

our students, to give their
introductions, some background, then we'll jump
into the substance. Erin, you want to start off? ERIN KAIVAN: Yeah, absolutely.

Hi, I'm Erin Kaivan. I served in the United
States Army for seven years before coming to school. And I was a military
intelligence officer.

My last duty station
was at Fort Campbell, with the 101st and third
brigade, Rakkasans,

family and legacy. GEORGE RIEDEL: Good, cool. PHILLIP JONES: Hi everyone. My name is Phillip Jones. Very so much, Erin,
I joined the military

because throughout my family,
at least four generations have been in the military.

My parents are both Air Force,
so I had to break their heart and go to the Naval Academy. Sorry, Mom and Dad.

But from the Naval Academy,
I did Marine Corps Infantry for six years. Two amazing deployments.
I had a great time. I'm also from Virginia as well. And I'm a RC here at HBS. GEORGE RIEDEL: Good, Jessica.

JESSICA STEPHENSON:
Hi, everyone. My name's Jessica Stephenson. I come from a long
line of military,

just like everyone else,
apparently, so far. My father was the
first one to serve as a career military
officer after graduating

from West Point. I did the same, my
brother as well. I served as an aviation officer
and then attack helicopter

pilot. Some people know
them as Apaches, and that's always interesting
to explain that here at HBS.

And see, as far as post-HBS, I'm
looking for general management opportunities, and just very
excited to be here today.

GEORGE RIEDEL: Good, thank you. TIM BUEHN: Hi there,
I'm Tim Buehn. I'm originally from
Jacksonville, Florida. I think I just watched
Top Gun a couple too

times, so always
wanted to do it, always wanted to
fly for the Navy. I was lucky enough to
go to the Naval Academy.

I'm a 2009 graduate. Was in the Navy for 10 years. Flew F-18s and then
switched over to F-35s.

And I'm now here at HBS. I was able to do some process
refinement with the F-35 program, and I'm kind
of hoping to continue

that in management consulting
after my time here at HBS. GEORGE RIEDEL: So terrific. Well, given it's
Veterans Day weekend,

we thought it would
be time we'd have a discussion with you folks. I'm going to ask
these folks a set of questions about different
phases of their journey

to get to HBS, and the
transition into it. So go back to when you were
thinking about applying, and talk us through what
was on your mind, what

were you thinking about, what
were the challenges before you came to HBS. Erin, can I start with you? ERIN KAIVAN: Yeah, absolutely.

I'm in the danger seat. I sat right next to you. GEORGE RIEDEL: Yes, you are. You're too close. ERIN KAIVAN: Yeah, so before
I ever even thought about HBS,

I think I was in fifth
grade when I first heard the word Harvard. I was like, that sounds
like somewhere I want to be.

So it was always in
the back of my mind that I wanted to get a
master's degree later on. And so I was in Afghanistan
for the first time

when actually one
of my friends was talking about applying to HBS. And he talked a lot
about the school

and what he hoped to
get out of the program. And so that dogged kind
of like my initiative, and to start
researching the school.

But before I applied,
I was in Afghanistan for the second time,
and I was really worried about taking the GMAT
because I could only take

the GRE while I was deployed. GEORGE RIEDEL: Interesting. ERIN KAIVAN: Yeah, so
I was really worried if the school actually was going
to kind of look at my tests

the same way they look at
everyone else with the GMAT. And so that was kind
of one of the things I was most afraid of.

And so all I was able
to do was take the GRE, and I did it on deployment,
and here I am today.

So if you're only
able to do the GRE and you're worried about
that being a prohibitive factor for the school letting
you in, don't worry about it.

There's some of us here. And then I also was
wondering whether or not I would find the same mission
and purpose on the outside

as I found on the
inside, in the Army. And I really can tell you that
it's not the same experience.

You're going to miss
the camaraderie, you're going to miss
the friendships. But you can find a lot of the
same things on the outside,

and you just have to decide
what's important to you. And I know, for me, I wanted
to have an impact a little bit

sooner, I think,
on a larger scale, and I thought that through
business and through the HBS experience, I'd be
able to do that.

GEORGE RIEDEL: Terrific. Phillip, what about you? PHILLIP JONES: I think I had a
very kind of similar approach.

For me, the biggest, I guess,
hardship would be the GMAT. And I would encourage
all the veterans,

start early with that
process, whether it's the GMAT or the GRE. Definitely take the time. It's a very difficult
test, but if you

start a year or 18
months before you apply, that's more than enough time. There's so many people that
want to help you succeed,

so definitely do
well on that test. Coming out of the
Marine Corps, I knew that I wanted to switch
to the private sector,

to give me just
some more experience in that part of life. I'm really interested
in economic mobility

So I was thinking about
law school or an MBA, and I kind of sailed
in the middle. So I'm a HBS-HKS degree.

So I'm doing an MBA
and MPP to kind of get the private sector and
the public sector combined together.

GEORGE RIEDEL: So
it's a dual degree. PHILLIP JONES: It
is a dual degree. So it's two masters
in three years, first year at the
Kennedy School,

and then the second year at HBS. Third year is going to be split. So that was kind of my
not law school, but not--

it's a hybrid, if you will. GEORGE RIEDEL: All right, good. Jessica. JESSICA STEPHENSON: So for me,
I wanted to stay in the military

and teach at West Point. I wanted to do that in an
engineering discipline. So early on, I
had been targeting

what kind of graduate
schools could I go to. So I had prepped the GRE
years before business school

would ever come into view. When I decided
that I wasn't going to be able to stay
and make a career

in the military, due to
some medical reasons, I started looking
at opportunities. And I saw a few
of my friends who

were at West Point about
the same time as I was, who were here, doing very well. And I was like, they
can go to Harvard.

I can go to Harvard. And started to look into what
exactly their lives were about. PHILLIP JONES: Sorry.

That's fine, that's fine. JESSICA STEPHENSON: What they
are doing, getting an MBA, and what that meant
for your future. I got really excited
about the opportunity

to continue in a
leadership capacity. And ultimately, I mean, it's
Harvard Business School.

To develop leaders to make
a difference in the world really struck a chord with me. So I threw the Hail Mary pass
with the GRE, and I'm here.

GEORGE RIEDEL: Fantastic. Tim? TIM BUEHN: I
couldn't agree more. That really resonates with
me, the emphasis on leadership

here. That's something that
was important to you in the military, that will
continue to be something that's valuable at HBS.

I know for me, I
just had some friends who had gotten out of
military and pursued MBAs. And so the opportunity
to potentially

have a greater impact,
potentially still in the public sector, using
kind of private sector solutions

is a common theme I've heard. So that's kind of what
I'm interested in doing. In terms of some
worries or reservations

that I had as I was
applying, I think I over thought my story, my narrative
kind of, which some of you

out there applying, you might
be struggling with that too. It kind of turned into a
don't overthink it thing.

I mean, you're a fighter
pilot, you're a Marine infantry officer. These are all amazing stories. Whatever you did
in the military,

that is your story, and just
kind of stick with that. And I think that's what
eventually helped me out the most.

GEORGE RIEDEL: Terrific. So you thought about it. For different
reasons, you apply. Some folks have concerns
about are they ready

for Harvard Business School. And I know we do
a number of things to help prepare, the Certificate
of Readiness for the summer program, for whether it's
analytic skills, or economics,

or finance, or stuff like that. Were there other
things that you did to help prepare
before you came here?

TIM BUEHN: I've
actually got one. I might have over indexed
on the preparation. So I, on the advice of
a friend-- actually,

another former Navy pilot. He's been retired
for some time now. But he is in
investment management,

and he said, hey,
the CFA level one is like an MBA kind of
compartmentalized into a box.

So if you study for
that and pass it or not, it will get you into
that rhythm of studying, and kind of that
academic momentum,

which 10 years out now from
undergrad, I did not have that. So it definitely prepared me.

A lot of material, I've
at least had exposure to at this point because of that. And it also just got me into
the habit of budgeting time,

studying, and I think
it definitely helped me hit the ground running here. So that was usually helpful. I don't know if I'd
recommend that for everybody.

There's a lot-- HBS has some great
resources which are probably better tailored. But it's a good
certificate, that if you

want to pursue that, you have
that check in the box as well. GEORGE RIEDEL: Terrific. PHILLIP JONES: I
can probably speak to the other side of that. So I did not do that.

I spent my EAS summer traveling
around different countries, so I didn't have
the time for that. But what I did do was I did a--

GEORGE RIEDEL: For fun? PHILLIP JONES: For fun,
for fun, I promise. But I did the HBS
core curriculum.

So it's essentially divided
into analytics, economics, and I forget the third one.

But it's a three
part series and it prepares you immensely for the
RC or the first year at HBS.

I didn't have a
finance background. Being a infantry officer
in the Marine Corps, we've didn't really talk about
the finance aspect of it.

ERIN KAIVAN: Margins,
what are those? PHILLIP JONES:
Yeah, margins, ROI. But it took about
2 and 1/2 months. You can do it online and
it's very, very helpful

for me and my first
100 days here at HBS. ERIN KAIVAN: Yeah, and I
think that maybe the lightest

solution is
something that I did. The school actually gives you-- I think it's like six months
for free with Wall Street Prep.

And I found that to
be really useful. I had never heard of
financial modeling. I thought it must have
been like this 3D thing.

I couldn't fathom what it was. It turns out it's just an
Excel doc, really simple. But the school gives
you the resources

to kind of get spun up on
those types of requirements that you're going
to have to do later.

So I got some exposure to
Excel and some other accounting terms, just through
this free program.

GEORGE RIEDEL: Terrific. So it sounds like a-- sorry, Jessica. JESSICA STEPHENSON: So I worked
all the way up until a month

before coming to
school, so I didn't get to do any of these,
which sound like great ideas. I highly recommend them.

But if you're crunched
for time, like I just started going
through every podcast that had Harvard Business School
or the Harvard Business Review

in it, anything I could get my
hands on from the Economist, really paying attention
to like, how could I

talk about this in
an educated manner, with other people who
have this experience? So if you have the time, all
of this sounds really great.

I definitely didn't, and I feel
like it was time well spent. GEORGE RIEDEL: Good. So a range of
different solutions,

from the over indexed
to a like that-- PHILLIP JONES: Like a
pilot, it sounds like. GEORGE RIEDEL: Because you
have a checklist to do this?

TIM BUEHN: I did. GEORGE RIEDEL: OK. So you get here. Tell me about the
first 100 days. You sort of walk into this
place, it's a bit daunting,

I suspect. Tell us about the
first 100 days. Tim, I'm going to
start with you. Tell me the transition story. TIM BUEHN: Yeah,
first 100 days, so

if you're leaving the
military, like all of us and as many of
you will be doing,

that is a whole process in and
of itself, leaving the military and then matriculating here. I also worked right up
until the last couple weeks,

so that was just a huge
hurdle to get over. I was kind of dealing
with life issues,

in terms of just
getting our household goods to our new place,
getting moved in.

Just the timing of all that
was very hectic for me. On top that, I'm married.

I have two little girls who
are two and six months old. So that was busy as well,
just the whole transition

for them, new place, new
environment, and all that. So it was really hectic.

I would say that if
you do have a family,

it's a little bit higher barrier
to entry with your section, and you might have to
get your life squared away first before you can
kind of dive into that.

On the other hand,
the whole FOMO aspect, the Fear Of Missing
Out, with all the events and social things,
I did not have

to worry about that, because
I kind of had my priorities. I had to focus on my family. So that dominated
my first 100 days

as well, just kind
of the adjustment to the academics
and the schedule. GEORGE RIEDEL:
Which was tougher, the academics, or
the sort of move,

or the social challenges, or-- TIM BUEHN: They
were pretty equal. I was trying to
balance everything, but I'd say they were pulling
me all in different directions,

but fairly equally so. I tried to divide it
up as best I could. The other big thing
that surprised

me was just the tempo of-- in the military we used to-- an email comes out
with action required,

and it's usually two weeks out,
I'd say, something like that. And if it's not, the person that
sent it did not prepare well.

Here, it's typical
that you get an email, and it's like, I need this
tomorrow or this afternoon. So I was not ready
for that, and I just

missed some things because the
turnaround was really quick. So be aware of that. Stay on top of your email
and all that kind of thing,

so you don't you don't miss
out on some potential section events, and just
bonding, basically.

GEORGE RIEDEL: Terrific. Jessica, what about you? JESSICA STEPHENSON:
So I definitely hit the ground running and wanted
to focus on my academics.

So the first thing
that I did was I started talking to student
academic services about, could I get tutors?

I knew I was going to need them. With some of my
medical concerns, how would I work that
around with appointments,

and how were the professors
going to work with me on that? I also did a lot of trying to
figure out which career path

should I start looking into. I wasn't sure when I showed up. And that was where I think
those time-sensitive decisions

about to sign up for different
career talks or industry panels became really
important early on. And so for anybody else out
there that doesn't really

know what they want to do
in their next phase of life, I highly recommend, say
yes to everything you can.

But make sure to take
care of yourself, leave some time for you. Because at the end of
day, it's very busy here.

It's been a year and a
quarter and some change, and it's just flown by. So in those first 100
days, just try and settle,

and pick a couple of paths that
you're really interested in. There's always time to correct. GEORGE RIEDEL: Very good. PHILLIP JONES: Yeah,
I think I would say,

there's so much
to do here at HBS. You have to be deliberate
about how you spend your time. For myself, I know I
wanted to do well here.

So I was very, very keen
on doing well academically. So I studied a
lot for the cases.

And also, I was very
involved in my section. So section I, I love them. They're amazing.

But there's always--
there's probably two section events a day. So I was doing grades as
well as section stuff.

I think I made a
good combination of combining both having fun but
still studying very, very hard.

GEORGE RIEDEL: Good. Erin? ERIN KAIVAN: Yeah, absolutely. The first 100 days
were so daunting. I was 5 and 1/2 months pregnant
before I came to campus.

And I was so worried. I was like, is anybody
going to be my friend? I was like this
giant pregnant lady.

But I could not have
imagined the warmth I was going to feel
from my section mates, from everyone else
that I've experienced

at school, the support
from the professors. Luckily, I didn't need much. My daughter was born like five
days after the end of the exams

the first semester. So timing couldn't
have worked out better. But even with academics,
because I also overly

indexed on academics, not coming
from a business background, I really wanted to
make sure I was getting the most out of my experience.

But the amount of time that my
classmates offered up, in order to help teach me
accounting, and finance,

and some of these very
hard technical skills, I was blown away. They would spend like an
hour or two out of their day

just to try and help teach
their fellow students, and I thought that that
was really incredible.

GEORGE RIEDEL: Let me follow up
on a couple of topics you guys raised. In the military, you will
talk about unit cohesion. In here, we have a section.

You want to explain
what a section is, and how they
operate, and what it means in terms of the social and
other aspects of the community

here? ERIN KAIVAN: Yeah,
you have the section. PHILLIP JONES: Yeah, I think
I can say I have the best section here at HBS.

ERIN KAIVAN: Boo. PHILLIP JONES: Anyway--
section I. So the way HBS divides the section,
or divides the class,

is in 10 different
94-person section. And so you take all of your
classes with that section.

So you see them-- so you sit in one seat
two or three times a day for six months, and they
switch it at the end.

So it is 94 people who usually
become very, very close, almost like a platoon or a
company minus, if you will.

You see them all the time,
you go to parties together, you study together. They really form the first level
of your friends here at HBS.

GEORGE RIEDEL: Terrific. Others want to add
anything about the section? TIM BUEHN: Yeah,
I would just add that it makes HBS feel small.

I mean, there are almost
1,000 people in your class, but your section is
kind of your unit. And you're going to
know all of them.

You'll be shocked how quickly
you learn everyone's names. I mean, within a few days,
honestly, for the most part.

And then that small unit kind of
facilitates your branching out, because they're
all going to have friends in different sections.

And it just makes
this place feel so much smaller, and
just so much more honestly like a family.

And your section will
absolutely feel that way. So I think it's a great way
to make this place manageable, even though there's 1,000
people here per class.

ERIN KAIVAN: Yeah, and I feel
like it really has transcended into second tier as well. Some of my best moments
throughout the day

are when I just run into
random section mates that I wasn't expecting. It just like-- it makes
you feel like you're more

at home at school, after you
have these 100 very close friends. GEORGE RIEDEL: Terrific.

You both also-- several of
you touched on other support services, whether it's the
student academic services,

or career planning, SAS
and CPD in our speak. Can you talk a bit
about what they've

done to help you in terms of
how they support your journey? JESSICA STEPHENSON: Sure,
I'll kick that one off. So student academic
services, very helpful.

They run a lot of
different clinics, like how should you
be reading cases, how should you be
preparing for cases.

And when it gets time for exams,
how do you respond and write a final exam when you're
given a case and a prompt,

and it's like, OK, go. So I really enjoyed
all of their clinics. They're wonderful people. You can schedule an
appointment, or be like me

and just drop by
and ask for help, and they'll help you either way. And because they just bend over
backwards to help everyone.

It's the friendliest
customer-facing staff at any institution that
I've ever participated in.

Whether it's your ed
center or your university, everyone here just wants
to see you succeed. And I would mention, oh,
you know, my back hurts.

Is there anything we
can do about that? And they're like, oh yeah,
actually, we've got chairs. We can give you a standing desk.

They came up with all sorts
of different accommodations that I didn't even
think about asking for. So if you've got anything
going on in your life,

they're there to help
you, academic, personal-- they can refer you to somebody
if they don't have the answer.

And then CPD was just
as helpful in trying to find the fit for you. You can make
special appointments

with career
advisors, and they'll hear, these are my ambitions,
these are my goals. And then they try
and help you find

ways that you'll feel
fulfilled in your life, or things that might
be a good fit for you. And again, just amazing people.

Every time I go in, I leave
with at least two or three more people that are like,
look them up on LinkedIn. They're a section mate of mine.

They'd love to talk to
you about X, Y, or Z. So just super outgoing
and very helpful. GEORGE RIEDEL: How about others?

SAS or CPD thoughts? TIM BUEHN: Yeah, just to the
even like pretty conventional level. Like, if you need a
tutor, they're there.

I signed up for tutoring for FRC
in [INAUDIBLE],, so obviously, I didn't do enough
before I entered, in spite of [INAUDIBLE]--

so yeah, I signed
up for a tutor. And they're actually typically
second year students. So maybe you guys are
tutors yourselves.

But that just makes
it really relatable. And they just went through
what you're going through now, so they totally
understand your situation.

And they're all very good, and
they're very happy to help. So that was phenomenal for me to
get that kind of targeted help

and feedback from them, and
resolve some issues that I wasn't understanding in class. GEORGE RIEDEL: Terrific, yeah.

PHILLIP JONES: And I think
a lot of the veterans don't want to ask for
help, whether it's for finance, or accounting,
or for other things.

And I would say, I think
the stat is 20% of people here actually use
the tutoring service. So I have two tutors, one for
finance and one for accounting,

and they've been
very, very helpful, helping me achieve high
grades during the midterms. So it's hard for vets to come in
without a financial background

and do well here, unless you
take the time to either study or get a tutor. ERIN KAIVAN: Yeah,
and it's free.

PHILLIP JONES: It's free, yeah. ERIN KAIVAN: Which is
amazing, because I've never been anywhere where so many
of these services are free. GEORGE RIEDEL:
It's a good point,

because I think there
is a stigma associated with asking for help. And the last stat I saw, I
think roughly half of the class

ask for some kind
of SAS service-- PHILLIP JONES: Eventually, yeah. GEORGE RIEDEL: Eventually, so
it's a well supported area.

A couple of you talked
about family and partners. How does that fit in
the community of HBS?

Is that easy? Is it hard? How does it work for them? ERIN KAIVAN: Absolutely. So I might have had one of
the more unique situations.

So my husband is
still in the Army. He's stationed at
Fort Bragg right now. And so we've been
doing long distance.

We did long distance
while I was pregnant. And then once that
was born, he was in Iraq, so we really had
kind of the full gamut

of long distance relationships
and managing that with children.

But it's 100% doable. My mom, luckily, was
able to come up and help. But there's a lot of
daycare centers on campus,

and students can utilize
that if they need it. But I think what was the most
helpful for me was just how

welcoming everyone was to me. I brought my daughter to
like every section event. My mom came.

So just like how welcoming
everyone in the community was. And then if you're a mom,
there's a mom MBA group.

There's just so many small
niche clubs that are-- it's like they're hand
tailored towards you.

It's really cool. TIM BUEHN: Yeah, I was
going add on to that. My section has been so
supportive of my family.

So they love Anna, my
wife, and Margot and Milly, our daughters. They even love our dog.

We show up, and it's a lot. It's kind of overwhelming,
but we roll in. But they're amazing.

They make us feel included
at pretty much every event that we do. I will say it's challenging,
just because your time is

for cases in the evening. And then at this
point in the year, we're doing a lot of recruiting,
depending on what field you're

interested in. So that takes up
a lot of your day. So your partner will--

they'll be wondering what
you're doing all the time. But I think there's just--
it goes to expectation management, communication.

Helping them realize
and showing to them the support network that's
available through HBS

makes that all a lot more
manageable and easier, and it's been at this
point challenging at first,

but it gets better every day. And it's-- we're really enjoying
the experience at this point already.

GEORGE RIEDEL: Different
topic, how approachable are the professors here? How much relationship
and time with them

do you get outside of class? ERIN KAIVAN: Yeah, as much
as you want, more or less.

You can schedule appointments
to meet up with them. You don't have to talk
to them about class. A lot of them have
either side projects

that they're working on, or they
ran like this massive business before school. So you can pretty much talk to
them about whatever you want.

But I've found that they've
been very, very accessible. You can either talk to
them before or after class. Like I said, you can go
to their office hours.

And everyone is more
than willing to help you with anything else
that you need. A couple of professors helped
me link up with other resources

when I wasn't sure where to go. And so I felt like that was
one of the most enjoyable experiences here, was
just in the long term

connections I'm going to have
with some of my professors. PHILLIP JONES: I would say I've
gone to office hours or lunch

with all five of my professors. ERIN KAIVAN: Yeah, the lunches. PHILLIP JONES: Yeah,
so lunches are awesome. There is small group,
six of your section mates

and your professor. You can talk about anything. So it's never about work or
about school, but just about,

what is your passions? What are your goals? How can I help you? And I think HBS does a
good job of facilitating

that conversation. JESSICA STEPHENSON: I would
say professors in general are extremely generous
with their time.

For my Fin 2 professor, I
scheduled a 20 minute office hour call just to say, hey,
by the way, this is hard,

and I'm really trying. What do you recommend I work on? And it turned into an hour
and a half tutoring session,

where she walked me through
the basic building block, where I was getting
stuck repeatedly. And I just was
like, wow, I don't

think I had any
sort of attention like that when I
went to West Point. Very small classes, but if
you asked for office hours,

it was hard capped
at 30 minutes. But she found the flexibility
with her schedule to make sure that understood this one topic.

So that's just the best
example I have for you. TIM BUEHN: I've just
got one quick anecdote which should be hopefully
appreciated by this audience.

We had our Veterans Day

essentially across

And just to give you an

So I kind of shared

to come here? What was the sort of
tough decision aspect? Phillip, you want to start?

PHILLIP JONES: Well, I

on a day to day basis. I think it's hard
to find that mission outside of the military.

And so for me, it was a
deliberate choice of OK, I know this, I know
the Marine Corps, I know where I'm going to be
in the next 5 and 10 years.

But I'm going to make a choice
to leave it, and perhaps-- So personally, I want to go back
into some type of public sector

service, whether it's Department
of Defense, Department of Navy. I was making a choice
to leave the military,

gain some experience
in the private sector, and then hopefully go back in
some capacity as a civilian,

to help kind of make it more
efficient and run better. GEORGE RIEDEL: OK. Jessica, what do you think? JESSICA STEPHENSON:
Yeah, I think for me,

I wasn't planning
on leaving, so I think that was first
and foremost the hardest part about leaving the military,

And having to make

and people that I

once that part was over,

I threw myself wholeheartedly
into this new life. And the only reason I've been

is because of the relationships

but my section mates have

have been at different times,

whether it's been being put in

So I'd like to be
known for other things. And my professors as well,
Professor, really, you

were one of mine who was there
to listen, and there to-- this is what I'm thinking,
but I'm not sure.

And it's OK to not
know, and there's going to be people who help you
do that, and figure that out. TIM BUEHN: Yeah, I think
one of the obvious answers

is just the camaraderie,
the fear of leaving that. In my case, honestly, I wasn't
running away from the Navy.

I just-- I had kind of done
everything I wanted to do, and I was really
running towards HBS.

It was something that
was a big goal of mine. So I was-- yeah,
it was bittersweet. I was sad to leave, but
happy to come to HBS.

I would say, for me the fear
of like, buyer's remorse, you know, that this was
kind of my dream job, I had done everything
I wanted to do,

but am I going to leave it,
and all of a sudden realize-- once it's really

But I haven't felt that yet. And I would just say that even
for the camaraderie piece, it exists beyond the military.

So the veterans group
here is a great example. I think that's going to

so I've been happy to see
that since I've been here. GEORGE RIEDEL: Terrific. So when you think back to
your application process,

and if you had to give
advice about what you thought stood out from your story, your
narrative, your application,

what would you-- what would be the
one or two things you'd sort of highlight
for others to sort of contemplate about?

TIM BUEHN: I can take this. Kind of like I mentioned
a little bit already, my big thing that I took
away from it was just

don't over think it. Whatever you did in the military
was, because you're so in it

and you're so
involved in it, it's hard to see just how
impressive it is, just how significant or
impactful it probably was.

Talk to people who
aren't in the military. Bounce whatever your
story is off them, and try to get a sense
of what that impact is

to them, somebody who's not
familiar with what we do. And I think a great way to
kind of gauge your story

and really, really get
your narrative down. So for me, that was
what I struggled with, and at the end of the day, it
was like the most obvious thing

in the world. You know what I mean? I had deployed to
Iraq and Syria, and been involved with
counter-ISIS operations.

And that was just what I did. But people-- not
everybody gets to do that. So that was kind of
part of my story.

ERIN KAIVAN: And I just
want to echo something that you had mentioned. I think that the school really
values leadership experience,

and that's just something I want
to reiterate to the audience. It doesn't matter what your
experience was in the military,

you were a leader. So I think that that's something
that the school really values. And so don't-- like you said,
don't get wrapped up in like,

oh, am I telling
the right story? Because who you are as a person
and all of your experiences really have culminated in

that the school would love
to have in their community. GEORGE RIEDEL: Terrific. So going back to the
daunting interviews that

were part of the application-- JESSICA STEPHENSON:
God, my heart. ERIN KAIVAN: I know, I'm like-- PHILLIP JONES:
[INAUDIBLE] and I sweat-- GEORGE RIEDEL: You've recovered. You've recovered.

[INTERPOSING VOICES] What surprised you or stumped
you in the interview question?

What was your least
favorite aspect of it? PHILLIP JONES: I think for me,
so I was in the field all week. So I was outside, I was
camping in the field.

We had the Marine Corps Marathon
that Saturday at 4:00 AM. Did that, and then I had
to fly straight to Boston.

So I kind of came here
already a little bit tired. I got ready, I got music. I stayed at my best
friend's house in Boston

and I walked into the interview. And I think for 30 minutes,
I probably blacked out.

But I think the question
that got me was, what type of leader are you? And I just kind of froze.

Like I had just been
a platoon commander. I had been charge
of a lot of people. And it was such a
simple question,

but I froze for probably-- it
was probably only four seconds, but for me it felt
like 35 seconds.

And I had to stop and be like,
OK, what type of leader am I? And so that was kind
of my tricky question.

JESSICA STEPHENSON:
I think for me, the interview was
extremely intimidating, because I ended up stepping
into the room with Chad Losee,

just one on one, no scribe,
like they tell you to expect. And so like, it's
all on this, Jessica.

If you piss off the
Director of Admissions, you are not getting in. And two questions
really stood out to me

as unusual, just in a leadership
story, tell me about a time when you struggled. I told a story about
having a difficult soldier

once upon a time, and I just
kept getting, and then what? And then what? And eventually, I
was like, it was

a verbal negative counseling
right there on the spot. How did he react? I was not expecting them to
run down that path so detailed.

And then the other thing I
would just tell you in general, they are very well prepared. I was surprised at the
level of which they

had internalized information
inside of my packet. And I said something
very casually, like, I've always
enjoyed coaching.

At the very bottom
of my resume, it says that I had been
a youth soccer coach. And Chad's response was,
"Yeah, that makes sense.

I mean, you volunteer
as a soccer coach." And I was like, oh, they
really read every detail and try and get to know
you before they come in,

so you can have a very
normal conversation. GEORGE RIEDEL: Got you. TIM BUEHN: Yeah, I agree
with the preparation thing.

My question surprised me. I got a little a little
push-back question, which was,

are you conflict-adverse,

bore you with the story, but that was one
of the big lessons

job in the military, is that I probably
was at one point. And so just being able to walk

that, even if they're-- they're
definitely not adversarial, but they might push on

So if they take that

and what you've done,

So I went to the

GEORGE RIEDEL: Yeah. ERIN KAIVAN: Yeah. GEORGE RIEDEL: So you-- ERIN KAIVAN: Oh, so sorry, I
just want to follow up on that. If you're not able to go to

like 30 seconds

before the interview

PHILLIP JONES: I would
